Lucy   July 1. 1850  Hampden                                             Hampden July 1st 1850                  

                                                     Samuel has gone to Bangor, Jane to school, and I am left alone. We had a fine time coming down, only sorry we did not bring Lute. Stopped two hours at Bradford, most of which time I slept refreshingly on the hard narrow sofa. We were just in time for the stage dinner. Samuel went to the table. I did not - he brought me ham & potatoes, bread, & butter, strawberry and custard pie. I did not feel as well that day as for some previous days - was very tired at night, slept almost all day Sunday, feel quite nicely today. We got here some after five. Jane came with a fine lot of strawberries soon after, and who do you guess next? Charles Harlow, of course! Very glad to see us -very sociable etc. for half an hour or so, then wished to speak alone with Samuel, wanted to borrow five dollars and give good security! He would probably have got it if I had not previously heard of Eliab's trials. I pitied the fellow - to walk away down here to ask such a favor of an almost entire stranger, and be refused too! Albina's bread was good - and quite a blessing to us. I hope you'll think to send my green veil by Lucy. I forgot it. Mrs. Goddard is very sick again with her breast - worse than ever. They feared she would have fits yesterday. I expected it when she came up here that damp morning. I forgot to talk all I intended with Almeda about her bonnet. If I were in her place I would have a black straw, lined with black, if she prefers it to white, trimmed with crepe or ribbon just as she likes, and a plain black lace veil with broad hem - all of which would be very cheap and proper.  These I would have purchased immediately. I wear them this summer light & comfortable as
Completed

They would be. Then in the long rides & stormy weather of another winter I would ear the old, and save the new one for another summer.  Say now, will you not give directions as to price, style of trimming etc. and let me send one right up? There seemed to be so much to think about and so little time to think when I was at Milo, many things were forgotten as usual. I hardly know what Mother concluded about her parasol. It seemed all the way home as if I had hardly seen any of you. Shan't Samuel and I go keep Pa's farm, live up there with you always? I half want to - only I am not fit for a farmer's wife. Mrs. Thaxter and Lissie Doe were down Sat. afternoon. I staid stowed some split peas for dinner Sunday, and built a rice pudding - Peas real good. Toast and strawberries for supper. Eliab came down. Guess I'll go lay down now, and finish my letter after Lucy comes. Mother's account which she wished for I have taken from Samuel's day book. If she can pick out all the shoes, she will do better than I can. 'Tis just the same as your so I won't send it. I have bought 1/2 doz. more 'kerchiefs - two for Albina. Tell Almeda I did not think what I was about when I took the 3.00 for Lucy's use & behoof, as I intended to get her whatever she needed.  With her permission I will forthwith use a part of it to get her bonnet - will she not write immediately her wishes & conclusions? The bacon is good as ever, Mother, & I am cooking it for dinner this day Teusday. Pegotty is "pretty comfortable." Samuel has gone strawberrying - making a business of getting some to preserve.

       Lucy got here safe and sound last night- pretty tired from jolts and jams. Has helped me make some bread, and pies from the green strawberries & currants. Samuel, Jane & Bridget picked eight pounds yesterday, which with Samuel's assistance I preserved this forenoon - had more than I expected to get. They are not near so thick here as at Milo. And so Isaac's going away - it seems as though he must'nt, and yet I know 'tis best. I am glad he has so good an appointment. What in the world will poor Josie & Mother * all the rest of you do? All losing your father & guardian at once? The matter of Alfred Holman shall be inquired into, & information given as speedily as possible.
Completed

[top]Sweet Briar with what grows on it for Joseph. Some of you ought to give Alfred employment after he gets to Milo, had'nt you?
Dear Mother                                                                                                                                     Hampden July 9th 1850.

                                 Alfred Holman came down here to day made us a good long call and took dinner. I am very sorry it has happened so, he understood that he was wanted immediately if he went to Milo, and has lost his place where he was at work, in consequence is now out of employment. He is going to Milo tomorrow and I hope Charles or somebody will hire him, so he need not lose his time. I like him better & better - he seems really kind hearted & good, says he should really like to go and take care of Joseph if he can - seemed to feel very much for him. I hope you will not fail to get him when Isaac goes away. 'Tis not every one that would find such an interest in Joseph as he does. I think him a whole hearted fellow. You would rather have him about the house than some folks too. I should rather give considerable more to have him. when is Isaac going, where, and what to do? Why can't you write me a word about it? I was intending to go to Bangor this afternoon to get some things for Lucy etc. but Samuel is surveying at the Mill all day. Surveyed at Bangor for Treat & Hardy day before & part of yesterday, went to Old Town for Hawthorne yesterday P.M. I am smart as a steel cricket - have grown strong and well ever since I came from Milo. Mrs. Finnigan washed yesterday - most three weeks wash, you know. Lucy and I have done all the ironing excepting calicoes. to-day , I did most all, besides getting Pea Soup (which
Completed

was amazing good!) Custard pudding and warm bread for dinner. Lucy is low, but very nice and faithful about everything, which is worth more than dashing you know. She and I did a real baking of beans, pudding, apple & currant pies, bread, fried doughnuts, and got a boiled dish for dinner besides, last Sat. forenoon!  In the P.M. Jenny churned, I fixed the butter and worked over all the rest, putting in more salt. I found it would not possibly keep. Lucy is very quiet and thoughtful, much more considerate than she used to be, needs a little reminding now and then, but is very good to think of things without being told. I have the girls sleep in separate chambers, for the well-being of both, and as I judge, the particular comfort & benefit of both. To relieve Almeda's mind about Lucy' looking old womanish, tell her I have once more made it more scanty & fixed little sleeves. It is enough prettier to pay for it., did not look so well before as I expected. Lucy is a good large girl, but not a woman yet. She is in Mrs. Jewett's class in S.S.  Likes her very much. I went to meeting sabbath afternoon. Mrs. J. and Hannah Moore enquired kindly and particularly for Josie and Mother. I am going to get Lissie Boid or somebody also to cut my new calico. Think I shall get Lucy a Gingham & have it cut at the same time. I have bought two kerchiefs for Albina, which I will send then John goes home if they do not come down and there is no previous opportunity, Lucy says Almeda wants some too.  Think we make quite a business buying handkerchiefs and shoes. I have already got ten kerchiefs, and will get more for
Completed

Almeda and Lucy if they are not gone. Sidney Thaxter & wife made me a call last Friday. Strawberries are being gone here - my preserves are very nice. Eliab says so Never did I see gooseberries hang on bushes so thick as they do here. Alfred insinuated that he would do Mrs. Searles' haying if she had not already engaged someone - thinks he can work for the "Major" if no where else.

               I am going to take Lucy with me to Mrs. Crosby's some day. Brown wants Samuel to go way up somewhere where he scaled this week, guess he will go Thursday - he gave a week or more - John will keep the horse down there and come here nights. Senator loading again- gone ten days this time. Samuel will earn something with her, if he don't have work, won't he? We had about done haying! only he has been too busy to get in the hay to-day. Jane is pretty fly away at home, but as near as I can learn is a real good girl at school. She got in a phlurry of passion at Mrs. Dove's disputing about the comparative beauty of Charlie and Mrs. Bickford's baby with somebody she never saw Charlie or heard of him before - only made believe to hector her. Said Charles was like an own brother to her, she would'nt stand that etc. and finally went off in the other room and screamed just as loud as she could, till Mrs. Dove, after coaxing a good while, threatened to inform me if she did not to go her supper in just five minutes. Jane told me all about it before I saw Mrs. Dove, which looked well in the child. What a letter I have written, and only intended when I sat down, to say a few words about Alfred. Wish you'd any of you write so to me. Eli & John were here the 4th. Good bye  Affec. daught. Lucy.


[ Previous letters spelling is Lissie Doe, here her mother is referred to as Mrs. Dove]
Completed

10 July - This letter has been in Eliab's possession - forgotten to mail - a good while. I will now put in a word or two & send it because I can not spare time to write another before  goes to Old town. This morning at six o'clock. It is now five. Day before yesterday Eliab came with two great white horses and three girls - Liz Doe, Mary Pomeroy - who is on a visit at Bangor- and pretty little Miss Lunt whom I had never seen before. and took tea with me. He sent the night before to me, so I had time to prepare - had previously some mie? cake made, made some tarts real nice, some of the best [[Milk? emptings?}} bread you ever saw, strawberry preserve, & currants mingled with sugar - we all had a lively time you may imagine. I some tired of course. Yesterday good brother Temple made his appearance about 9 A.M. stopped till after ten - He & Lucy seemed almost
[postmark] BANGOR ME JULY 19                                                                                 5

                                                                     Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf
                                                                                     Milo
                                                                                                 Maine

overjoyed to see each other. I think he is a real good man. He invited us very strongly to come up to the Seminary Friday, when we go to hear Mr. Little's eulogy on Pres. Taylor. Think we shall go on Lucy's account- should like to have her visit the Seminary. Isaac only came in here fifteen or twenty minutes. I will write about it next time. I was so disappointed. Sweet Briar I had not time to press - is not in very good shape - but believe 'tis just the season now. Will try when the grass is dry if I can get another. If Almeda could see how delighted Lucy was with her cotton, she would write every week I know. In awful haste   Lucy
[upside down] Lucy Hampden July 9 1850
Completed

Lucy Hampden
July 12. 1850

                                                                                                                                                  Hampden July 12th. 1850.
                             Father came last night after John - is going home tomorrow if he does not tonight. I send four kerchiefs for Almeda and Albina. There are two more here which Lucy is going to hem & use while here, & Almeda can have them or I will keep them just as she likes - tell her to write. Lucy is quite impatient because Mother nor James have neither of them written yet. Why did they not tell me what to do about a bonnet, so that I can send it by this good opportunity. When is Isaac coming?
              I bought a small plaid pink muslin for Lucy yesterday could not find a pretty gingham. This is stout & does'nt fade - also aprons, stockings. gloves etc. Samuel got twenty pounds of beef - leg. after steak was cut off - for, 25 yesterday very fat -such lots of marrow and fatings.  - pieces of marrow half as large as my fist came tumbling out which he cut it into. We had a good steak for breakfast, s[t]enough for a dinner to Mr. Goddard - have a nice soup for dinner, and am cooking the rest, which is a great boiler full, to make mince pies! Called to see Lissie Doe yesterday. She is acquainted with Mr. Temple. The night before I gave quite an account of Milo & the country round there in a vestry meeting at the first parish, she says he is considered quite talented and an excellent scholar at the Seminary, but is exceedingly eccentric much ridiculed by some. I am thinking it will take Isaac some days to pack, he has so many things accumulated at Milo. If you get this before he comes, wish you'd
Completed

send me one or two of your good turnips- can't get any here but little this years english - don't like them. don't forget my veil. Prof. Webster's confession, Gen. Taylor's death, dreadful fire & lots of life at Philadelphia etc. you have probably heard of before now. What valuable affair the Telegraph is!

Send back Anna's letter first opportunity.

                                                            Mrs. A.M. Metcalf
                                                                                  Milo

right side and bottom upside down I have just been out in the yard and picked beautiful white rose buds, blush and hundred leaf with buds, making a most loveable boquet. I'm saving them for Samuel but I'd gladly cheat him out of them. & give them to Josie or Mother if I could. Our peas and taters are in bloom. Mrs. Crosby called night before last. Guess I'll have a nice lot of mince pies tomorrow. Wish I could send you one. Samuel does not go up river. Wish Joseph would send me some of his 'Testers' he told about to put in my book. Samuel is haying this week for Mr. Goddard who cuts the hay on this place. Lucy and Jane have gone over on the hill to look for Blueberries. Wish we had any raspberries down here. Suppose they are beginning to open at Milo. Have just finished bosoming Libe's shirt and making his collars/
Completed

Lucy & Samuel     Hampden                                                                                                     19th July
Dear Mother & folks
July 19. 1850

                                               Lucy has begun a letter to her Mother - does not make very good heading- she needs to practice - finds it very difficult to express herself she says. I try to help her, but she thinks I can't very well. Mrs. Goddard's sister is fitting her dress today. I am desirous to get it done for her to wear next sabbath, as he other one is somewhat soiled. If Almeda has a fine white skirt which she can send as well as not, perhaps she had better, to wear under her muslin. Am having it cut high outside, lining loose with adging round the tip. Almeda must it think I am extravagant - the child certainly needed another dress here. She & Mr. Temple seemed as pleased to see each other as our brother & sister. He seems to feel very much for the Milo people. I have made Lucy a small plaid, blue gingham apron, looks real pretty. I was much disappointed not to hear Mr. Little's Eulogy on the President today, but it rained. Samuel has engaged with Mr. Hathorne the same as last year. Is at Old Town lots lately, and expects to be more next week. Sat. P.M. Lucy's dress is all done. -sets beautifully. The poor girl has pretty hard work writing letters - she has been so unused to excitement that the company got her all into fidgets the other day. Jane would enjoy just such a spice every day, but Lucy would not endure it much better than I should. They did carry on. I tell Lucy she must try to learn herself to be calm under all circumstances. I had a number more things to say, but the hurry of finishing off Lucy's dress made me forget them. We are going to visit the Seminary some day. Isaac had been looking for Eliab after the stage for in till most
Completed

dark - had just started with a horse to come down here, and met him with his girls going home. So he got in with them turned about & all posted back here about nine o'clock. I had just unrigged, put on my old loose dress and laid down - didn't care though anything about it.

 Lucy had just gone to bed when they came back, said she could not compose herself. I feel happy at all, but when she read her Mother's letters, it calmed her at once. Says she is perfectly contented & likes to stay, if Almeda is willing, I should like her to stay till school is done - four weeks longer.

Lucy thinks I ought to write a few lines to Joseph. have nothing of interest to say have been at work for Hathorne last week $55 per month he has bot a stock of logs for the mill. his two purchases of logs amount to $30,00, without even seeing one of them. I got to Old Town tomorrow morning shall be there most of next week, write to us often

                                                                                                                                                   SWF

[upside down] I don't think I could possible stand it to have Jane at home with her. Shall have to send one of them away certainly. Jane is such a fly away, I have the girls both go to meetings forenoons, and I stay at home, on account of S. School. Then I go in the afternoon & take one of them. I was very sorry not to see Isaac more.
Completed

Lucy Hampden

 Aug. 1850

Dear Mother, Joseph & all
                                          Lucy seems to desire to go home, and as I do not now need her help. I am going to pack her up and put her aboard stage tomorrow. It is Sabbath night & I cannot write much - you much wished for letter came last week, but not a word about the school or sick teacher which I requested so particularly in my last letter and which Lucy was in a twister? to hear about. I send two skeins unbleached cotton (which by the way cannot be obtained so good as in old times,) and  two 45 spools for Mother 2 Albince. The tidy I feat will be rumpled - 'tis not so large as I intended to make, but will do better than none. I have got my rug (sewing on pieces) most done. I spoke with Hannah Moore today  - she is going to Hartford a week from next Thursday. I will endeavor to get the book, and call on her this week. The other things Eliab will get before he goes. Mr. Brown is going away, and he cannot as he intended, go this week. Am exceedingly obliged to Joseph for his care of my fictional book - hope he will send me something - I send Smellies Philosphy for him. Samuel says I may take Jane and go up and stay as long as I wish - he will board at Hardy's - but I do not think it will be expedient or proper, though I do want to go and stay with
Completed

dear Joseph, and write for him, and help him and love him. I want to see you all much. You inquire for my health. My health is verry good, Thank you! I am writing to Ann. Eliab has your last letter and I don't remember whether there is any thing more to say in answer or not. Paper and ink can not conveniently be sent in Lucy's bag. Eliab will take them. Do write - do write - do write often. How does Albina do, and why don't she ever write to me? How does Charles stand in taking care of Joseph? good night - Your affectionate daughter & sis, Lucy.
P.S. Letter from Isaac last week - the poor fellow seems to have much responsibility and care. I hope he won't get sick - says much about not hearing from Milo. Mond. noon. I will get 1/2 ream of paper and some ink when he gets to Bangor if there is time.

                                                                                                                                   good bye

I send enclosed ten dollars on a/c

                                                                                                                   S.W.F

                                                                                                               Mother
Completed

Lucy & Samuel  Hampden
Aug. 3. 1850

                                                                                                                            Hampden Aug. 3rd 1850.

Dear Mother and folks

                               You don't writ to me, and don't write to me and don't write to me, till I am sick and tired of not having so many letters! Some little scribblings to Eliab or Josie's business etc. and a little meagre note from Almeda, mostly to Lucy - no more for a long, long time, when I want so much to hear of every thing. No letter from Isaac yet, either. We learned from John, who came Teusday that Alfred said Joseph was certainly better - stood alone in the floor for a minute.
 Samuel is busy as busy can be in the mill, up to Old Town etc. Bennett was so little respected and consequently so much imposed upon by the mill men, that Hathorne got out of patience and turned him out of the synagogue this week - our friend Abel Hardy takes charge now. The day before Bennett left as he was passing under the step, some one poured a pail of cold water directly on him - wet his best hat and "go to snutins'" sadly. That is only one of many things that were constantly taking place. Day before yesterday Lucy and I spent the afternoon at Mrs. Crosby's. I have made seven tumblers of currant jelly - real nice - and Jane is picking the Gooseberries to preserve today. I have made Lucy's dress - she has worn it to meeting two sabbaths - my new one, and had my pink muslin and pretty blue calico made over in fashion - also made Jane's
Completed

light calico that her Mother sent her - her "bonnet with reafs," you know. We do not have much of a school, and I am satisfied that Jane would learn more at home than at school, of everything useful at least, and if your teacher has commenced again, I think Lucy had better go home immediately, as she ought to go to school - our school does not keep but a fortnight longer and I would just as lief Jane would not go another day - besides I am as strong and well now, as before I was sick, about, and could do very well with what Jane could help if she did go to school. Lucy and Jane are both good girls - Jane is much better than when school first began - only flighty - but take them both together, my patience is tried sometimes. Lucy tries to do right, and is a real good girl, but Almeda has allowed her to be so slow and puttering, that I fear she will never learn to be really smart and quick about work. It is an utter impossibility for her to hurry on any occasion. Tell Almeda from me that she had better do better with Lissie - of she does not work but an hour in a day, let her move that hour. It worries me to see any body drag round in the heat two hours ti do what might much easier be done in half an hour. We have not yet visited The Seminary, but intend to that and Hardy's just as soon as Samuel can "get time."He is much poorer than ever I saw him before - constant care and vexation with paddies and "green hands" that don't know anything. You must'nt expect me to come to Milo again this summer. I will think of you and love you much here as well as there, but can't think of breaking up your
Completed

no how - am so glad I went when I did, so as to see Isaac a little.= - how did Josie like it to have him entreat Alfred away - good chance for Alfred. I am glad for him, and probably Isaac could not get another so good in ten towns. If Joseph, our dear Joseph, is getting better any, why in the wold may I not know it from himself, or somebody that knows, instead of partly hearing of it in a round about way? It is not fair not to write more. Just a fortnight from the time our peas bloomed, we had a mass of green peas, and they have grown astonishingly, could have a mass every day, and do, almost. How different they are from those Samuel bought in the market - tasteless things. Lucy's muslin dress was cut Friday forenoon and I finished it, every loop and stitch, for her to wear to meeting Sunday, besides taking all the forenoon, my big jar full of gooseberries. What shall be done with the black currants? One mill man's name is Asa. Mr. Hardy spells it acy Acy! You remember Mr. Emerson, don't you Josie? I don't feel right about it that Prof. Webster is to be executed. Gov. Briggs is too good a man to be accessory to such an act. Mr. Temple shows himself at The Hall every sabbath forenoon! We have cucumbers and do all eat them. though I wish we would'nt! They is good. Why don't Isaac write to me? You need'nt trouble about Lucy's being green and awkward - she appears well enough, only stares a little too much. We wish you to write the next mail after receiving this whether your school is teaching. If you don't, you may expect to see Lucy home before you are
Completed

"ready for her." Sat. eve. Samuel has brought me no Cutters today, so I'll finish and send this by Monday's mail. He says he'll write a little to Josie dear, so I'll leave the rest of the page. Lucy will write next time. Do, do, do write to me. Lucy.
Samuel says I am too hard a nag to Almeda - but you know how much it all means - nobody knows better than I that Lucy is one of the best girls that ever was - amen.
To J.M. Metcalf Gentleman
I learned to night, that Omnibus is numbered with the things that were and that the Independent California bill was taken up in Senate by a majority of thirteen. I expect for the rest of the season to be much confined to the mill at least so much that it will be a waste of eyesight for you to look for us at Milo. What an overturn as turned up at the mill this week six men some of them so long here that they felt like real estate have, been discharged and Chauncy C. Bennett gone home to recruit. Schooners work slow this year the Senator has now been gone almost four weeks to Cambridge. I learned to night that Miss Hannah Moore is engaged to the Hartford association for a teacher to go to the West. S.W. and wife Lucy 
If any of you want any more shoes or handkerchiefs let us know before Lucy goes.
Completed

Lucy says there are a great many things that she wants to say to her Mother, but she cannot put them on paper - says she is going home so soon she will wait and speak them by word of mouth.

    A great Circus in Bangor last week. Our good Prof. Shepard said he went to see the Circus and was very much pleased with their movements,. What do you think of that? Explanation. They were passing by - he went to the window to see them, and was pleased with their movements because they were moving out of town! Old City Hall has been moved back - is going to be fixed over and be used temporarily for a third Parish meeting house. Prof. Shepard is going to be our Pastor. ? for Mother - 'tis no use for me to do it up, as it will get tumbled going home. Starch is very stiff, lay it on a table or bed & pull it all out.
Completed

even and let it dry so, then twill be stiff and keep in place. Mr. Crosby's 'hypo' is going off gradually. Warren Furber has a recent son. There's a darling pretty way of making drapes - new - which I will send a pattern of to Albina if I can get it before Lucy goes home - loose in front with sack to fit the form behind. Seems to me there was a deal more that I wanted to say, but can't think if it now. 
Eliab talks of going to Milo next week. If he does, guess I had better send Lucy. good bye.
Completed

Lucy & Samuel Hampden
Aug. 13 1850

                                                                                                                                                     Hampden Aug. 13th 1850.

Dear Mother

                 It is after breakfast next day after Lucy went home. I was amazing smart yesterday, and Jane was just as good as mortal could wish for. Though the poor child cried by spells all day about Lucy's going away. I expect she'll make quite a person yet notwithstanding she is so passionate and fly away at times. I did the washing, (washed a web & a piece of new cloth besides) got the clothes all out, boiled a blueberry butter pudding for dinner, made two huge loaves of smacking good blueberry cake, and two loaves of bread. Jane washed the dining room and kitchen floors as nicely as I could do it, did up the work, waited and tended it, and  - we got all done, hair combed, dressed up etc. a good while before the dinner- but - I went & laid down on the sofa after dinner & unwittingly fell asleep with nothing over me, and in this way, or by the wind blowing on me when washing out on the platform, I got cold in my head & neck, and the way head teeth and all did jump and sing! as if they enjoyed it better than I did! Samuel got up in the night made a fire and established me in the rocking chair with a comforter round me, prepared a nice dish of cocoa, if thereby I might get in a perspiration - as I was preparing to drink the same, the dish slipped in my hand, and what a piece of work!
Completed

as good luck would have it, it was not quite boiling hot, though it made me smart some, but comforter shawl and nightclothes - O my! Well I changed my clothes, got excited into a perspiration, drank what was left, wen to bed, slept nicely, and am all over it this morning. It seems lonely enough since Lucy went away - she is very quiet generally, but a good deal of company after all - more companionable  for me than Jane is. She left her sun bonnet and knitting work here. I will send them by Eliab. I had the pleasure of seeing Mrs. Wooster Parker last week in Bangor, said she had been wanting to go and see Joseph ever since he has been at Milo.
Aug. 14th Samuel brought me your letter this forenoon - good folks - well done. If you have written a large double letter any time since I was at Milo, it was undoubtedly lost somewhere, as I have never seen it. Finished my rug and ironed today. The rug is real pretty. So it is. It was considerable work, but I do not regret the time or labor, 'twice be a piece of workmanship for folks to remember Lute by when she is dead and gone, you know. Well I am glad Eliab is going up - wish I could go too. Jos. your friends - "occupation, operations & prosperity" - M. Crosby not quite through her school of 16 weeks on the Avenue road grows poor upon it too, but is much liked, and laboring to do goo. I see her occasionally at church. H.A. Moore I generally say "how do you do" to sabba' day - she has had a bad cold- starts a week from tomorrow for Hartford. Mrs. Jewett shakes hands hard, when at all. Mr. J. smiles, bows, looks glad to
Completed

see me, and every body else. E. Boyd I very seldom see or speak with, as she sits 'together side and gets out first. Turkey Savory I never heard of before, and know nothing about. J. L. Ricker smiles & makes the "salaam" when I see him, which is not often. L.D. Thurston has just gone into partnership with Samuel sending a load of ashes to a quaker somebody somewhere! Thats all I've heard about him for a long time. Ann Thurston is spending the summer with friends away - her health improved. The Dea. sings constantly and vigorously at the Hall. "Lydia" comes to meetin' every Sunday. When I come across her path, she looks out of her funny eyes, and nods her head at one. Can I give you any more satisfactory information? hey? Bancroft's Hist. U.L. Mehitable was reading. I thought I should much like to. It is my intention to go to Bangor tomorrow, purchase the desired "Lady", call and sat good bye & leave it. I wish & wish & wish that Samuel could sell Cub and buy Beck, but then I could not drive Beck, and he could not let her: Cub, you see, more than earns his keeping all the time, hardly a day but somebody is after him - sometimes so we can hardly get him to use ourself. I don't know what I will think best about it. I am writing to Ann - have had no letter from her for a long time. I do hope she will come this fall. If she would come home, and Josie dear get well, how happy we would be! I don't know really, Mother, but it would be punishing brother Dole enough to make him read your writing with good ink, unless you cross your tias and dot your ayes better than you do sometimes. Have Eliab take back the trunk. so if I should take a notion to go
Completed

to Milo, of which there is small probability, I could have someat to pack my things in. The hosen which I send (Janet's are getting too small) please color most anything but black, at your convenience. I think that birch bark is a beautiful color for stockings. If you can conveniently before winter, I wish you would knit Samuel a pair or two of gloves. He will need a pr. of coarse and one of fine. I'll knit a pr if you'll send me some yarn! Ain't I good and obliging? I have made my gooseberry preserve and 'tis nice. I wish I had something more to say, but don't see as I have, guess Samuel will write some. Jane is first the best girl -don't know how long it will last? We have no Cholera here, but Dysentery (bad form) is very prevalent.

                                                                                             Image of horse with "On horses, or asses." written across its body

Well as for horses I don't know. I ought not to sell Cub, he is worth more for Coutts than Miss Bee, and I can get the hay for a hoss of Coutts best of than any other man. I know that Rebecca would not be of so much present value as Cub but would be improving if Coutts will buy Cub and promise to pay me $70. I will buy Bee if I can pay as soon as Charles wants the money if he wants to sell for $100, perhaps a note on three months would pay his debt, if so I could buy, but if he wants cash I can't trade - we are having to repair the plant, & timber say $400, which will keep me rather short. Capt.Jellison moved to Belfast last trip and in consequence he looses more on less time every trip. Guess I must look up another Capin. Eye umed Hathorne foretene dolens tu daze thiss weke Know mowen til deth              acy 3hmensun
What do you spose has got into Samuel
Completed

Dear Mother

               Lucy? Lily?did not go today as I expected last night - she and Julia came back about 11 A.M. to start new tomorrow morning. Charles Harlow dropped in unexpectedly  to dinner - queer fellow. Capt. Stevenson caught and kissed me vigorously, whereat his better half rebuked him and he said it was not a carnal kiss, but according to scripture, greetings with a holy kiss! A monstrous great crazy beggar came in today. The first one I ever saw that I was afraid of I believe - send down for Samuel, but he was gone before he got here. If there is any pretty good grass to be attained up there, I wish some of you would call and save a few handfulls for me. Eliab said fall meadow, and blue joint I believe, had not gone to seed. I had quite a lot of various kinds, but let Mrs. Thaxter have them as she could not get more. I suppose swale and meadow grass are yet in bloom, and they are prettiest for vases, because drooping - if you find any please stand them up in an old pot or something, so that they may wilt and dry drooping, put them in a paper & send them by any convenient opportunity. Samuel Thurston introduced me to his little wife last sabbath. Tiger would'nt go with Mehitable this morning though I gave him an extra breakfast in consideration of his journey, - he seems to like living here pretty well. Jane is today offered a cent for
Completed

every morning that she will get up by five o'clock.



Mother
[upside down]Lucy Hampden

                        Sept. 1850
Completed

Lucy                Hampden
Sept. 11. 1850

                                                                                                                                Hampden Sept. 11. 1850

Dear People at home

                                  I went shopping yesterday! Purchased the one pr of hose in payment of 25 cents, which was all I could get. The other two for Eliab has to give to Mr. Temple, who is yet in Bangor. Mr. Kimball as left - what shall be done with the towel? I also got ten yds of the above mentioned sheeting for Almeda and five for Albina (just enough for a pair of chemise, and very pretty for it too I think.) should think it would be pretty also for children's nightgowns when bleached. You will find this kind all in one piece - 25 yds. For Albina five yds / 4 per yd     .32
               11 3/4 yds, 4 cents " .47
               11 "            9 cents ___99
               3/4 " linen, 50 per yd  37 1/2
                1 brown table cover       75
                1 salt cellar                    10
                                                  $3.00

I could not find any 8 cent sheeting very good. Thought this 9 cent was nice. I put in a bit like what I was making at home for Samuel - you will see it is a min. quality. Thought eleven yds would make Charles two prs of shirts. For Josie's shirts I got 6 yds of the same kind. Ten yds of ,6 1/4 and a 1/2 of, 4 for Almeda makes just a dollar, besides which, from her funds I paid the remaining , 30 besides what the stockings pd for the S. Circle. This is a jumbled up mess - don't know as you will understand it.  Charles Harlow called again yesterday
Completed

I have no doubt he is deranged - appears more and more like it. I do wish he would not come here so often. What can I do about it. His cold clammy hand makes me think of Uriah Heep in "Copperfield."

     Notwithstanding Samuel is "repairing the Senator," and is short just now, he felt it his duty to subscribe ten dollars towards purchasing an Organ for the Central Church - Second hand - Mr. Jewett says probably the handsomest one in the state - great bargain only $800. The Sewing Circle are going to get it, only the gentlemen are to help them find five hundred dollars! Have two hundred or 250. towards it now. Mr. Jewett gives 25. Mr. McDonald $80. etc. It was drefful warm the day I came down - stopped for the stage & Jane half an hour or more. Began to rain before we got quite home - rained all night and next day.  There was not a bit of rain here while I was at Milo. It is raining now (Wednes. eve) special hard. Ivor Brild says he hardly ever knew a more healthy summer - take it through. Mrs. Thaxter called yesterday. She came down to spend the day while I was gone. I called to see Lissie Doe yesterday - gone to Glenburn to help fix two brothers off to this cousin. Tell Charles in the overflowing goodness of his heart, he became naughty in sending so much of "that corn." We ate upon it with all our might (dinner of it today, but too old & be very sweet) all we could, and were obliged to give some dozen ears to Mooly today. The cheese is nice and is fast disappearing.
Completed

on previous page disappearing Hasel nuts - I remitted a proper share to Eliab. Pickle am in a fine state of preservation. I put them in brine soon as I got home, or rather Samuel did, let them be till Mond. now, when we got some sharp vinegar, soaked them a spell, put them in with spice of divers kind and alum, where they remain hard and nice as you please. I don't know whether to let them be as long as they remain hard & good, or to scald them now, and I forgot to ask Mrs. Thaxter! My Mentor you know. Had to throw away part of my good pudding one and a part apple fries, half loaf of bread etc. Samuel gave one loaf to Mc Caffety's. He did not eat anything at all hardly. I made some cream tarar biscuit Sat. night and went to bed. Mond. Jane and we looked about to see what needed care all over the house, found my jelly moulding, scraped off the top, fitted papers wet with honey? to the tumblers, tied them up again, boiled an apple pudding for dinner, besides done other cooking, churned, did my fortnights washing, washed floors and all, and got done a little after noon - rung the clothes out after tea. Yesterday baked, cleaned up house and made all tidy against Mrs. Lee comes! had two callers (Mrs. L. and Chary Harlow) did a lot of sewing I went shopping - today, rested upon it! had the Committee to set off Mrs. Emery's Thirds all over and about the house. This afternoon, Jane is a fine help. She cried a good deal Sunday, and some since. Troubled because she got put out with the children, and coming away to leave them etc. Wishes she had something to send them, to show them that she loved and thought of them. I tell her I will give her a cent a day for getting up at five oclock till she can earn
Completed

J.M. Metcalf Esq.

                                                             I did propose to see you last Week, but was prevented by a press of surveying I earned. Mr. Hathorne in twelve days surveying $51, before I hired with him Mr. Brown tho't I was not competent enough to survey. it is all working just right, The Senator is now loading with dust. Hathorne expects to contract so as keep her at the dust business. Gunnings bill is about $800, he calls her good for ten years service, all that has been done pretty nearly amounts to new taking she now stand the owners of $1860, with some interest, the Brandywine is doing a poor business. got a return from the ashes to day they fell short in Portsmouth of the measure some 450 Bushels. Thurston & I lose about $4, each instead of a profit of $20, each which we should have realized if the cargo had held out. the quakers even too big rogues for Jellison. The Feltcher and Mayo matters remain in "Status quo." Have pd Whiting, shall pay McDonnald when he asks for it; Eliab gave me a meas. of all amts which you left with him for collection I suppose he is too busy to look after them this Fall. I suppose it to be perfectly useless to write to any of your Creditors, perhaps by following them up close something might be collected but think it doubtful, if there is nothing, any sooner perhaps next winter I can look after some of them. If Charles' creditor of Leaven does not want his money at present perhaps I should like to keep it  a few weeks and would pay the rate which he pays. Can I keep it if I wish? please.
                                                                                                                                                   S.W.F.

[left-hand side] Mr. Goddard went blackberrying, as I told you, fourteen miles - got 4 qts - cost him $3.50! Horse & carriage & lots of days time. Profitable, wasn't it? Shall I send the cloth and things up by stage or wait for another opportunity - will ask Mrs. Lee to take that for the S. Circle if she comes here, but suppose she would not want to carry all.
[top] enough to get some things. Just saw Eliab last night - hardly spoke to him. Well, I must write to Isaac tonight so I'll leave you all for the present, good night. I have forgotten whether Almeda wished her bag filled with coarse meal to send or not.
Completed

Mond. eve Sept. 16
                                       Got my washing all done, floors washed, bedroom and all, hasses and finepane rubbed, etc. toilet made and myself set down to rest before noon - been sewing this afternoon, and evening finished previously begun letters to Ann and Olive. Samuel is dilligently perusing the Tribune, & Jane gone to bed. Eliab handed me letters yesterday which somebody brought when the store was shut - he could not find out about purchases of cloth from those I received when at Milo. You have probably before now got my letter telling what I did buy. I understood Charles cloth for two prs of shirts. Can get more .4 if you wish. I will see Eliab & get a "great many funds" as Mr. Hardy says, and get the thing you mention to send when these go. Albina will find collar cut out, and shirt yoke pattern somewhere in the bundle. Almeda's bag also I will put in. My pickles are nice. They please me much. I put them in sharp cold vinegar. did nothing more to them, and in 4 days they were real good pickles, all made - green, hard & crispy as you please - so much better than those miserable Boston things. Musical Convention commences tomorrow continues  4 days - mean to go some if Samuel can leave. Prof. I.B. Woodbury from N.Y. is head. What a piece of work they have in N.Y. with Jenny Lind. I should love to hear her, but would not pay $125. for it I think. Richard Johnston preached yesterday P.M. How clever and sad he looks, and how exactly like all the rest of them. Ann Thurston has got home
Completed

I am tired and sleepy. 'Tis 'bout nine o'clock. I'll go to bed - so good night, dear ones all - good night.
Tues. morn. I'll do up the bundle and send to Eliab today to wait for a chance to go. Samuel will get the other things and put in, and I will not go up today. Please give the 'Kerchief to Persis, and do please to write to me oftener. Love to all - good bye. Lucy.
If you are going to color yellow, this face, Mother, will you color this flannel, but don't do it on purpose on any account, as I don't care a fig. In haste. Margaret Crosby and Augusta Mann called last week - were most pleased with Mr. Temple of any of the students at Commencement, and knew nothing about him previously. How shall I keep Charles Harlow off?
[upside down] Lucy Sept. 16 1850
Completed

Sept. 30. 1850.

Dear Folks

                        Spose 'tis time for me to begin a letter to you, as I received one from you Sat. night. Our husband went to Bangor and got it and Eliab. While he was gone John came, so we had company you see. I took them all there into the larder, - had just been baking you know, beside having a dish of blanc mange, of which they are all extravagantly fond - I guess they had a good time! First frost last night, covered up our squashes & tomatoes. Samuel gone to Belfast by boat today - back in stage this afternoon to see that considerate Capt. Jellison, who has "given up the ship," sent it to Bangor, & not paid over anything. Samuel & Thurston think he'll prove a rogue, but S. will write you about it after he come home. I got my washing all out on the line before tea today. Why, I wonder did not Mrs. Lee stop here? Tell her I don't mean to go see her anymore, if she will go right by me without stopping. Perhaps she don't want me to. Samuel & I attended Musical Convention Concerts two evenings - he could not leave in the day time. One eve paid.50 - the other, John being a member of the Association, got us free tickets - real good -sung one piece forty seven pages long, in the Dulcimer. "Oratorio of Absolom." I'll send a Programme if I can. Dulcimer is a new book - some of I.N. Metcalf's tunes
Completed

in it. Two fine female singers from Hartford - soprano and alto, and Prof. I.B. Woodbury from N. York. Writes poetry, and music to match!

  When we went to get 4 cent cloth for Mother - the Coat order - They asked 4 1/2 - Everybody but Sticking asked five. I thought it could not be got so long. Had to pay 4 1/2 for mine. Much obliged for your suggestions about C.H., but I shall have no need to profit by them at present. The poor fellow is in Augusta Insane Hospital - his father went with him last week. Poor fellow. I pity him - am glad he is gone there - he may be cured.
   Thurs. Oct. 3. Samuel is going to Bangor -guess I'll finish and send this. Dea. Romulus Haskins with his lady and oldest daughter called Monday P.M. Apologized much for not calling before - have intended to call ever since I was married! I guess after all my smartings to wash Monday, I got a shocking cold! I guess too, that our vegetable marrow squashes are superb. I'll save you some seed - had some for dinner yesterday. Have gathered some Penny royal for you too - believe it does not grow there. I went to Belfast Monday - saw Jellison - got no money  - said he had money but will pay when he can. Samuel is doubtful - sold  the Brandywine to one Capt. Small of Deer Island, for $1000. to go fishing. Pays 1/2 next January & 1/2 a year from then. Meanwhile the vessel remains in their hands. If he does not make the first payment according to agreement, they will take it back. I suppose Samuel would tell you all about it much better than
Completed

I can, but I want to send this tomorrow, and fear he will not have time. Am glad Charles has paid his notes. I would not borrow again - pretty advice for me to give too, when Samuel is even now doing the same thing! We look a very little for Anna next week. Am afraid I shall not be able to keep her here long, but Mother, I do think if you and she and Almeda are all there together, you might and ought one or some of you to stay with me part of the winter. Just because I am married and can't live at home, that I cannot have the privilege of seeing any of you -Jose, you send 'em along, won't you, that's a good brother. Spent an evening at Mr. Crosby's last week. Men gone to Cattle Show, and Margaret to Boston. Mrs. Crosby about alone. Mr. Temple has not been to apologize or to give him the stockings only in ? the meeting house at a Concert. I think Eliab might to make a business of it, and go see him. Cowper, Indelible Ink etc. shall be attended to by first opportunity. John made me a bottle of Ink 'tother day. 

  What beautiful weather - warm as summer almost A fine rain last night - cleared off very warm - Allura Dove has a daughter a few weeks old. Lucy has not yet written to me. How do I write with nothing to say. In much haste as usual - good bye
                                                                                                                                    Sis Lucy.
Completed
