I suppose Almeda wants to come down. And it would be nice if she & Lissie could come & make their visit & carry me home i.e. if it is best for me to go home at all before next fall. But then I suppose you want the to use the horse every day this long time. & perhaps too A. had rather come after they have got mov'd into the new house. I do want to be at home. And I want to be here with Lucy & Eliab if I could do them any good they are two poor lame backed creatures. I very much doubt whether Eliab had as much prospect of ever being well as Lucy has & she don't certainly get along very fast. 2 or 3 days during the winter she set up all day & 3 times she has made her bed. it was before she went to Milo. I get along quite comfortably with the work. But still I suppose it would be better for them to have a good Smart hired girl if they can get one. I really cannot make up my mind whether I ought to stay or not do tell me all of you what you think about it.

[top upside down] Dear Albina Will you please to do your best endeavor to get these tomato seeds planted in a good sunny place & I will try to keep the weeds from them when I get home. I'm some afraid they'll get lost out of the letter.
Completed

Charles my dear Son I want to impress upon your mind Eliab's idea that if you would bathe in cold water wash in cold water sit in cold water like it would help you as much as to have a hired man you would feel so much smarter so lively & strong (But by the way I scold him, for thinking so much of water) he comes home from his work, & so tired & his back so weak he can hardly sit up - then he'll go into his chamber & sit in a tub of cold water, then rub & wash himself till he is all in a perspiration - and go off to his work in the afternoon feeling quite well as he says. But I wish he'd use cold water a little less & that you would use it a great deal more e.g. wash all over once a day in water not very cold & rub and dry yourself thoroughly you would lose no time by it for your would feel so much better that you would more than gain it. You can hardly realise how much more dilegently and constantly the men folks so work here than at Milo. It seems to me that our 3 men folks are not idle an hour in a week put it all together they frequently don't get home to supper till half past seven
[upside down]20th To Almeda my Daughter We had awhile ago kind a fix up a plan to have (or see if we could have) you come here & stay 2 or 3 weeks (leave your cow & boy James at Charles's) while I went home & then 1st of July vacation will commence & Lucy & Jane do the work by hiring washing they are old enough & it seemed as if they might but when we came to examine it all round we concluded it would not do as Netty would not be in condition & you would need some fixing up to leave so long so we give it up - & Lucy is going to try & get a girl- if she can't make out to get a good one I shall stay and do what I can, perhaps Lucy A. can help some in the vacation. I think I could get along with the work but the so constant care is sometimes a burden - we have breakfast ready at half past five - write whether you and Lis could come and carry me home at the of a fortnight or 3 weeks if I should write to you that I want to go I cannot tell yet, you know, whether or when
Completed

Bangor June 21, 1852

                                                                                                                                   Bangor June 21 1852

Dear Brother & Sisters

                                Mother did not think of going home today, but has concluded to wait till Wednesday & so I will write a few words, though I have not much to say. I don't know how we shall all prosper when Mother is gone, but presume we can manage to get enough of something every day to eat, and perhaps get our beds made! I am very doubtful, Charles, whether Charlie will on the whole be benefited by attending school this summer. I do not think children should be sent to school till they are six years old. At home, frolicking about, they are laying in a stock of physical strength and stamina which will give them greater power and strength of intellect by and by, which they will need when they come to the labor of study. I don't believe it is good for their little bodies to be kept so still six hours in a day. How does Lissie prosper, Almeda. I suppose all her Motherlyness is put in requisition to take care of Charlie nowadays. Lucy's school is one week longer - if I get a girl I suppose she will be homeward bound shortly. We do not think that on the whole Miss Call & school is the most improving that might be - perhaps if Miss Littlefield is even displaced she had better come
Completed

and go there one term - that is just the school for her. So please to write often. I want exceedingly to go to Milo by & by, but don't know as I can.

 Please Charles if you can, do help Mother a little about fixing a lounge. It is very easy, and but little work. She can tell you a simple way as Mr. Tebbets fixed ours. I suppose you are drefful busy, but some rainy day you know.
                                          In haste
                                                                        Tis Lucy.

                                Brother to Sister
Completed

Bangor June 24 1852

                                                                                                    Bangor June 14 - 1852.

Dear Mother 

                                               You have been gone about a day so I suppose it is time for me to commence a letter to you. You know when anybody goes away from anywhere, there is always something (some time a series of things) happens more wonderful than usual that makes anybody wish anybody had staid a day longer. Well, we passed a quiet day yesterday, after our usual fashion - about tea time who should appear to us but Rev. Mr. Partridge, his wife and baby, to stay all night. They had been to tea. We received them graciously. Lucy and Jane trimmed round like women, prepared the "go to meetin' chamber," got things ready for breakfast etc. We had baked veal for dinner yesterday and some slices cold for breakfast with warm potatoes, bread & butter, & doughnuts, all ready by 1/2 past sic this morning. They went out in the Boston at 11 this A.M. Samuel gave Mrs. P. $5.00 as a parting present! I guess they feel poor.

P.M. Well, yesterday afternoon Lucy ironed all but the starched clothes. Those I have done this forenoon. So our ironing for the week is done. Lucy went to school this morning, but soon returned - no school today & perhaps not tomorrow - Miss Call's cousin
[left-hand side] If you would only write everything to me as I do to you!
Completed

bring himself last night - he was sun? struck in N.Y., has been here for a few days, partially deranged. Letters from Almeda and Isaac last night - the latter I send. I feel very anxious about him and shall till we hear again. A letter also from Antoinette, to Issac's address, rec'd last night.

                          About girls, I fear Almeda has put herself to unnecessary inconvenience & trouble about it - really my damsels get along as nicely that I don't think I shall trouble myself any further at present! provided Almeda will let Lucy stay. I was very tired last night. Lucy wondered what Grandmother would do if she should see my face, but I feel quite nicely today, even after ironing shirts. I have laid down a good long time, and am going to again. We don't have company every day you know. They are raising the house this P.M. Put the sills on yesterday. I expect it will go ahead now.
                Besides all the other wonders that I have written about, there has appeared a detailed account of the rat hunt of night before last, which I will transcribe for your edification. I have fixed Lucy's green dress so it looks sweetly - made it low in the neck with a row of small white buttons to button up the back - and cut the sleeve right off short! On
Completed

examination, I percieved that the sleeves were almost gone, and though the easiest way would be to peice up a new pair from the flounce to button right up under - they look darling pretty. I can't tell yet, but I think that after school is done, we can get along nicely. I think at any rate, we had better try it a while. It will be good for Lucy - she feels the care of it, and is so anxious to see to everything to save my bones! Well, I will leave a little room for her to write - do all write often. I want to hear how you got home, how glad they all were to see you and everything. In haste, Lucy.
Dear Mother

                            I begun a letter to send by Grandmother but did not have time to finish it. I do not know but we shall have company in to see our school tomorrow and I dread it for I shall have to read one of my compositions myself. Miss Call has chosen "Old Hero" my last one for me to read I don't know how I can do it. Miss Call was intending to have them come tomorrow but I don't know but the death of her cousin will prevent it. I was very glad to see Mr. Partridge and wife once more before they went away. I think their baby is very smart for one of that age. Miss Walker's girl from Sebec who attends the same school that I do) come up here with me to see them and they were gone. I was real sorry for she wanted very much to see them Ann Page has just come in and I cannot think very well so I will wait till she has gone. Ann Page has gone and I can't think of any thing to write and my hand trembles so I can't write it. I do not what I shall do about learning to write if I cannot keep my hand
Completed

steadier. I told Lissie I would write to her next time I wrote so I shall not call this a letter; perhaps I shall put one into the stand drawer when that is sent up. Aunt Lucy wants to know how they liked the crockery and clock. Do write often I shall have more time to write when school is done

                                                                                                                         good bye
                                                                                                                                    Your affectionate daughter Lucy A Searles

[post mark] BANGOR ME n.d. 

                                                                                 Mrs. A. M. Metcalf
                                                                                               Milo
                                                                                                    Maine
Completed

Bangor June 27, 1852

                                                                                                                             Bangor June 27 - 1852.
              Dear Mother
                                                     I do not approve of writing letters sabbath day; and seldom do it, but as we rec'd another letter from Issac last night, which I know you will be anxious to see, I will write a little to send with it by tomorrow's mail.
                                                    Eliab said I ought not to have sent his other letter till we heard again.,  but you charged me so particularly to forward as soon as we received his letters, that I thought I must.
                                                    Your letter was rec'd last night. In regard to the principal matter therein contained, I am wholly incompetent and unable to utter a word. we have not had time yet to think of it. Isaac probably know the most about the individual. "If this thing should happen" as you say, I don't know what we should all do. It would hardly be home then for any of us without Almeda close by. Of course it is for herself to decide, - in view of her own happiness & good, and that of her children. You were real good to write so soon. I thank you. So please continue to write very often. We get along nicely so far, the day after you went away, Ann Page came in to comfort me concerning my Mother.

[left-hand side] Mrs. Wiggins is very low - had watchers for a week - an attack of Asthma.
Completed

said she thought about it? great deal and wanted to come in the day but ? was not well enough.

             They had ? "melting time" at Miss Call's school yesterday (the last day) I conclude. Poor Lucy could hardly keep from tears all the afternoon. I thought she would feel better to be employed, so we went to baking. It is not strange that she feels bad - she has become very much attached to two or three of the girls - you know she never was acquainted with any girls that she really liked - kindred spirits - before, and now to lose them again so soon seems hard. She will write to her Mother soon all about it - she will have more time now. Perhaps Anna will take her in too with regard to her studies next winter. Yesterday P.M.Lucy prepared beans, brown bread & white, while I made five pies, and a batch of doughnuts & I say by the table and did the whole, then moved my chair to the stove & fried them. I also in the course of the day made up my new underbed. You recollect Mrs. Stowe says of "Marie" that when talkings of the troubles her slaves gave her, she always seemed to be "wonderfully supported"
Completed

I think I am ? wonderfully supported" when there is any work? to so, usually! Day 'fore yesterday I cut ?.

                      The house of ?- you can't think. I wish you were here, it seems so lively and refreshing to hear six men pounding, whistling, singing, shouting "heave ho," "give beam," "There she goes" "once more" etc. Mr. Tebbets wouldn't have one idle a moment, he says "come boys" and not "go boys" - always speak pleasant, (except when a stupid paddy tried his patience too bad) but in good earnest, and they all seem to know what he means. There were eleven men at work there yesterday ?, carpenters & lathers. If James were here, he could earn from thirty to fifty cents per day lathing, for a few days.  I think Charles prospects extremely flattering with two such smart hired men. Mr. Tebbets sister called here yesterday to get some more of "Catherine's" things - after she went away, Mr. T. opened his heart to me about the family. He has been treated shamefully & cruelly - he has had some miserable thoughts & feelings pent up within him since his wife died, besides his sincere grief for her. Says he never mentioned the subject to any person before. I am astonished that I have filled my sheet. good bye - Love to all.
                                                                                                  daughter Lucy.
Completed

[post mark] BANGOR ME 8?

                                             Mrs. M.A. Metcalf
                                                        Milo
                                                         Maine
Completed

Sabbath, July 4 - Tom's rec'd last night - greatly obliged. Sorry for your "sketer? factory" and all your other troubles!

           In regard to the urgent and important matter before treated of, we know nothing at all. Neither Samuel, Eliab and I know the man by sight, but have heard of the Riders in general as fine people - doubtless Isaac knows more of the character etc. of the man than any of the rest of us - if the case is so urgent that it will not do to wait for his opinion. I should advise to make a confidant of Mr. Sewall. He would, of course, know all about his. But why is the case so urgent - what is the hurry? I should want a long time to consider such a matter. You were not sufficiently explicit. How and when did the gentleman make known his

[left-hand side] Bangor July 4. 1852
Completed

wishes? What does Charles know about him? How old is he? How does he look? Above all, what does Almeda think of him? Of course he is a pious man, or it would not be thought of. It is Almeda's business to ask him all these questions and as many more as she sees fit, and then go to Mr. Sewell & see if he tell a straight story. Why in the world you come to us for advice I don't know - we don't know half so much as you to begin with, and have no opportunity to find out more whereas you can easily do it. It is for Almeda to decide. Guess I'll write a word or two to Almeda. About rags, no special hurry any time when convenient. I have tried to get Eliab to write to you. Will try to find your things to send by Gould.
Completed

Bangor July 2, 1952

                                                                                                                             Bangor July 2 - 1852

Dear Mother

                      I very much wanted a letter from you last night but did not get it, so to console myself for the disappointment, I will commence writing one to you.
                      We get along finely considering  - have got a window in the dark chamber and a bell- (O that we had before you went away)  - have had breakfast in good season every morning but one. The girls sleep in the "new room," and the "go to meetin'" chamber is all prepared for the reception of Aunt Anne. Our washing and ironing was done up in good shape by Wednes. noon. Yesterday we baked wheat bread, apple & rhubarb pies & fried cakes. I have made Jane's dress - it looks "very decent." Am now making another pair of these pants for Samuel. The "hard times" pr are too short & too small, do not look 'spectable. and I'm going to send them to Charles - he may allow what he thinks they are worth. I expect they will wear well. I am letting

[left-hand side]   Your girls too hard." - Old Olson with her grand son and a little young fox called here this week - wanted to see the fox. Why don't you write to Lucy.
Completed

The damsels read "Uncle Tom's Cabin" - for a sort of stimulus, you know - an hour every afternoon. Mr. Smith, the Librarian, was so accommodating as to bring it up here - both volumes - one day when he had business as far as the Rail Road Bridge. I thought he was very kind.

                     The house progresses rapidly. Mr. Tebbets has to wait some for Mr. Wiggin's slow motions. It is all partitioned off inside and lathed ready to plaster between the studs. The chimneys are all done but topping out one. Oven, ash hole, flat iron heater, boiler. I think it will be nice & convenient. The boiler is not set though - Samuel had to get one made. I have not been up there yet. Samuel has been unusually busy this week - and that is say a good deal you know - has had more orders than he could saw - running by night too - and has been obliged to get some sawed at the mill below. The first of next week if nothing happens, when he is more at leisure, I think of taking a journey up to the house. Mr. Tebbets
Completed

proposed to carry me up on a long board the other night, but I declined. They say there is a splendid prospect from the chamber windows - can see everywhar! We had a beef soup for dinner today - it was baked first though. We are expecting Anne next Teusday, but she may not come. Isaac, I presume, will leave her at Boston and go in another direction before coming at Bangor. A letter for you from Aunt Conant last night, but as there is no special news, I will not enclose it in this, as it is a big square one. Why did not Gould call for these things? Eliab saw him & sent the salt, but thought these articles had gone - please direct him to call. We got your likeness a day or two since - it is much better than the others - but it is your 'go to meeting face now. Samuel has written about the carraige - he will let you know as soon as he received an answer. Don't be worrying amd expecting the folks too soon. They will, of course, want to stop here a week or two to rest before they proceed to Milo. Samuel grows busier than ever lately. I begin to
Completed

feel more in doubt whether I can go to Milo at all.
Sat. P.M. We have bake wheat bread, pies, "New Year's Cale" - and fried some nice doughnuts today. I am getting ready for Anna., you see - made a lot of cake - the whole receipt - seven pounds of flour - It is real good. I like the blue cook book more and more. We did not bake in the brick oven - brown bread and beans seemed to go hard last week, even with Mr. Tebbets - thought we would have a  week's respite. O, we baked a pudding for dinner too. Samuel saw the nose and toes of a rat poking through the crack in the back room yesterday, so he loaded his pistol and fired. We could discover no dead rat - but think there must be one somewhere. Mrs. Wiggins continues very sick. Cannot probably live long. Why don't you all write? You ought to consider how like a funeral it seemed here after you went away, and write oftener - tell just what you're all doing every day as I do. Mr. Tebbets don't know which way to worry - he keeps telling me I shall do too much and get sick when I tell him I won't, he says "well don't you work
[left-hand side] How shall we get "Uncle Tom" up there for the folks to read? What was the dollar for in your last letter you said not a word about it.
Completed

Bangor July 21 1852                                                                   

                                                                                                                               Bangor July 21  - 1852

Dear Mother and all

                               It is so very warm that I can hardly write, but I will try to scribble a few words. It is a very warm day, and then we have been doing a big ironing, which has heated the house very much. I intended to have the washer -woman again this week to wash & iron, but Lucy, in the exhuberance of her goodness, had got the washing all done when we got home - was just putting away the things to, so I thought we would iron too. She did but a part of last week's ironing, so we had nine starched shirts and three bosoms today. Tuesday we watched five dresses and divers aprons etc. - which are put by for tomorrow. I as glad Mrs. Lee did not come yesterday, hope she will not till next week. We got home safe and sound about six o'clock. The girls got along nicely, only Lucy said it was hard to tell what to get for each meal. Mr. T.

[left-hand side] I have looked high and low for Aunt Conant's letter but cannot find it. I think it might have been sent in some of the things. It was certainly "sound" when the folks were here. There was so much confusion that it may have been mislaid. I shall find it sometime if it is here.
Completed

bought raspberries two or three times. They seemed pretty glad to see us back. It would be a good thing for Lucy to be left in charge of affairs a month. She would learn faster so than any other way. They are two good girls. I could not help worrying about you Mother for fear you would not take care of yourself - you get too much fatigued every day I was at home. So be careful this warm weather. The raspberries came very nicely but we missed the cream! Almeda's sugar I will send with the things if it is procured in season. The parasol is mended cost 2/. I sent the pattern of patch, but there was not enough like it so I will wait till I go down street. I have not done anything to the girls dresses yet - expect Miss Raynes tomorrow to help me.

         Among the clothes washed last week was a baby's nightgown, small, neatly made, - where could it come form? Nettie, is it yours? It is a great mystery to me. No one knows or can guess anything about it. Samuel has gone to Old Town
Completed

today - he is not well at all. The warm weather affects him very much. Isaac, I out in your jack-knife - you will find it among the things somewhere. We found the house clapboarded and painted, the front door built and the piazza made when we ca,me home, also the whole front part painted over once. The windows are in, and the stairs built. It is astonishing to see how things have grown in the garden within a week. We can have green peas tomorrow.

              Mrs. Wiggins is very low - they have had Dr. Rich - they start with her tomorrow morning for Boston, to get advice from physicians there. I don't know how they will get her there, so sick as she is. Ann Page made me a long visit yesterday. She says it is all over the neighborhood that Mr. Tebbets is paying attention to "sister Judith?" Mrs. and Wife Raynes called yesterday.
  Eliab says he shall start next Mond. for Boston. You know he borrowed a shirt of Mr. Tebbets when he went to Milo, there were five nice clean ones in his
Completed

trunk all the while. I send the Shibet dress - you can conclude together what is best about it. It is tea time - good night.

         Did you get anything for me, Anne, except Lucy's shoes & cambric for Jane's skirt? How much was my dress? I think I shall have it fitted soon. I have not had time to finish Isaac's shirts, so I will send them as they are. Eliab will get his clothes to send if they are done.
           Friday morn - I have been sweeping & my hand tremble badly. Mr. Livermore will probably be along soon. I will fix Isaac's clothes in as well as I can - wish I knew whether he or Antoinette want any of their clothes which were washed sent up. I don't know how much sugar there is Almeda. Eliab could not get 1/2 barrel of fish so got a barrel for $6.00. Lucy's dress is finished except sewing in the sleeves. Miss Raynes is to fit Jane's this morning. I should do it myself only could not have time to finish it. I think Mrs. Lee will not come this week. In haste - do write, all, - to Lucy
Completed

Bangor July 27, 1852

                                                                                                                       Bangor July 27 - 1852

Dear Mother

                        Your name as the direction of a letter seems to comprehend all the brothers & sisters too at present - at any rate, I must make it do so this time.
                         I did intend to write a long letter this time and not hurry about it either; "but" - yesterday we washed. This morning while the girls were doing the usual morning's work and a little additional cleaning etc., I made a custard pie for tea, some tart skeletons & a loaf of cup cake - to attend to the baking of the same, broil a steak for dinner, and superintend the operations of my two handmaidens was a good forenoon's work. Then so soon as I had done dinner & laid me down to rest, Samuel came, quite unexpectedly. to give me a ride. That, of course, must be done, - so we went over to his mill, & rode down two miles below it
Completed

on the Brewer side. Then back, did some little matters of shopping on Main St., patch & calico for Almeda & - made two calls without getting out of the carriage - at Mr. Kitteridge's & Bartlett's and home at 1/2 past five. It is now six. I have rested a few minutes. Lucy is picking over raspberries which we have just bought, for tea,- Jane making a fire. One of them must carry this to the Office tonight. Eliab started in the six o'clock boat Monday morning for the "Water cure!" Did not know how soon he should return. I don't dare to think of it, because it makes me feel bad that I cannot be at Milo with you all, helping you have good times.

        It was so warm & I had so much to do, that I dd not enjoy your visit here so much as I could now. Isaac & Nettie, and I really think you ought to come so as to stay more than a "day or two"  with me when you go back. When are you coming Anna. If soon I will not have
Completed

my first dress made till you come, but if not I shall need it. I got both the girls dresses done Sat. night, but have to hurry for it. Miss Raynes fitted both, which saved a good deal of time, If I am as well then as now, I hope to get to meeting next sabbath. Eliab bought some kerchiefs for you Isaac. When shall I send Almerda's things? I fear the calico will not suit, and I could get no good patch for less than /9 per yd.

                        I thank sister Nettie very much for her "few words," and shall be extremely happy to thank her again and again for similar favors - would answer it particularly had I time, but most defer it. Am glad it pleases her to have so many new brothers & sisters - there are quite a number of us - but we shall be glad to welcome about three more into the family. Nettie's "nickname" or whatever Anne calls it does not suit me at all, but as it is, I send it - please
Completed

report faithfully on all topics of interest, all of you - were you not frightened when Isaac was sick? Samuel is much better since he came home. How soon will Almeda come down? Lucy wants to see her very much. I do so want to be at Milo with you all, do write what you do every day. Lavinia told me today that they some expect to move away. Mr. Kittredge has just come in, so I must stop - good bye - I love all of you. In haste. Lucy.
Completed

Bangor July 31 '52

                                                                                             Bangor July 31 - 1852.

Der Mother,

                            Your good letter, dated all the way from the 24th to the 29th inst. was duly received last Thursday evening.
                            I do not feel very well about it, that among so many, no one could write a word but you, and so a sheet be sent half full. It seems almost hard to be away from you all now. Albina has a hard time about hep doesn't she? Worse than I do - my patience is sorely tried some days, but on the whole we get along pretty well - some days I feel obliged to work rather harder than I ought to, but I always get over it again. I had a sad time this week with that old bag of hen's feathers upstairs. The rats had gnawed into it, and it was fuller of moths & millers than you can imagine. I have seen more about the house in all the rooms than ever before this summer & could not think where they came from. I destroyed all I could.

[left-hand side and top] Anna and Isaac why don't you write? I have written ever so much more to you since I came away than you have to me, though there is nothing new here, and you all do some new thing there every day. Isaac has not written a word only a request to send up his knife. Please take into consideration my lonely sit = nation!  Amen.
Completed

Just the feathers, bag and all, in a tub of hot water - when they were wet through we took them out of the bag, Samuel dug a hole in the ground and buried them!
I find moths in his buffalo coat and every where - is there anything I can do about it now? Mrs. Lee came Thursday - took stage for Bucksport next morning. I have finished my muslin dress - trimmed it with double ruffles- the sleeves - don't think I shall ever do so foolish a thing again, was almost tired of it before it was made. If I feel pretty well tomorrow, intend to go to church half the day.

                 In regard to Almeda's arrangements, I don't understand  - it seems to me it would be the extreme of nonsense for her to make a wedding, or any parade at all - why not as she goes to her new home - children and all - call at the parson's, and let that end it, as many of you can go, ride over to Brownsville with her. I suppose I may give my opinion - and it is that I should do no such thing as to get an expensive dress just for that occasion. I should prefer to have a
Completed

a common dress suitable to ride in. Were I in Almeda's place, and needed another dress, of whatever kind, I would have it; but nice silk dresses are comparatively little needed in the country, and with all slightly unsuitable, as a general thing, to crowd into a carriage with a family and ride four miles to meeting. However she knows better what she wants than I do. I should think Anne's shawl would be just what she needs. When is she coming down? does she wish these things sent up before she comes? Have you rec'd my last extremely fleshy letter yet? We have not heard a word from Eliab yet. I some expect him tonight. I sent the pillow to take care of the parasol! Our house is entirely finished and painted outside - woodshed, piazza etc. Mr. Wiggin will finish plastering today probably - then Mr. Tebbets will go to work on the inside. We are going to have the walls of the kitchen painted all over.

               William Crosby wishes to know when Isaac is coming back, as he will come up here and see him. Margaret does not
Completed

gain very fast. Mr. C. is very bad with the hypo. People are talking of trying to get a chime of bells for the new Unitarian church. I hope they will.

                   Th story about Mr. T. and Judith is doubtless entirely without foundation. Mrs. Lee says Lucy has grown fleshy very much. Thinks I do not hurt her at work. From what she said of Augusta Brown, I should think her very much like Jane - very smart, high spirited, and disposed to be impudent. I think she is a trial to Mrs. Luard Ellen too. I have not called at any neighbor's yet - think I shall next week if nothing happens. I have just about as much as I can get along with every day to keep the mending all done and everything in order, without of yourself - you keep tired all the time because you will always jump to wait upon everybody when anything is wanted.
                 Much love to all - and do write. Mother, Charles, Issac, Nettie, Almeda, Anna, Albina, James - do write to us.
                                                                                                                      Lucy

[left-hand side] Aug 1st P.M. have been to meeting & feel nicely after it. One of the students preached ! too bad Please Anne tell me whether to have the pink dress fitted before you come. when will you come?
Completed

Bangor Aug. 7. 52

                                                                                                                 Bangor Aug. 7 - 1852.
  Dear ones all,
                                           A nice package of good letters just received - for which receive my hearty thanks. They were done night before last, but Samuel called the, and twice yesterday, when the Office was closed. Eliab brought them when he came to dinner. The table is just cleared away - girls dispersed to put away baking things, wash dishes etc. so I will occupy a few moments in writing.
                                         We get along very well usually - now and then a hard day. Samuel's care is very hard for him - he says the men very soon waste $75.00 worth of lumber if he is away. He says that my sewing here at home , - more than a hired girl would do, all which is very right and proper, - might amount to fifty cents a week, while the difference at the mill, when he trusts to his men, is nearer a hundred dollars. 
                                       I was particularly gratified with all the items of intelligence contained in 

[left-hand side]filled my sheet? My letters are to all - I cannot very well portion them out to each one. I like the plan much of bonnet for Almeda lined & trimmed with white and plain wool delaine dress - very suitable and pretty I think.
Completed

your several epistles, though to be sure I heard repeatedly that you have been to Brownsville! Thus much for Isaac to glory over!

                By the way, Isaac, about "straw" for your "brick," methinks you should be able to find enough of that commodity to satisfy the present emergency, in your own cranium, stored away there for "time of need," without being altogether dependent on making it up as you go along - eh? I beg pardon for my mistake about weddings. I did think it strange that so many sensible people together should go off on such notions. Nettie and I will do our best about suiting you with a dress, Almeda. I only wish I could run about up street and down without a carriage and driver. How would I attend to matters! Lucy seems quite disappointed that you do not come down. If my health is as good or better that at present, and Jane does not go to school, I think we can get along without Lucy next winter. It will be much easier doing the work in the new house, than here. I don't know what we shall decide about Jane's going to school.

[left-hand side]There is talk of getting a chime of bells for the new Unitarian church and they are trying to raise by subscription the necessary means to put a spire on our new church. I hope they will succeed in both.
Completed

Samuel thinks a little that he shall not go into the woods next winter. I have not a great amount of work on hand - nothing hurrying - and if you can send something entirely prepared when Isaac comes. I can help you as well as not. How much I d want to be among you, to put a "finger in the pie." You must send specific directions in relation to all purchases. I should think a dark all wool delaine just the thing you need. I like that material for dresses very much. Dry goods of every kind and exceedingly cheap now. All purchases of that kind had better be made now than a few weeks later. I got some crash a few days since for /4 quite as good as what I gave 10c for last winter. Berages ? - really handsome - silk and wool for 12 1/2 and 16 c - delaine for ten cents etc. etc. Silks are said to be cheaper than ever know before. A good time for me to get one, if I only went out often enough to make it worthwhile. I think some of having my silk made over - simple let out under the arms  and a yoke put in to bring it high in the neck, I have invited Eliab again &
[left-hand side]I wish I could think of something more to say! I rather like to talk to you all. Has Charles any help besides Shubal Knowles?
Completed

again to write to you - he says he thinks of you every day! I tell him you have no evidence of it, except my testimony. He ought to tell you all about his journey. There is here a small package sent by him from Mrs. Child to Anna. She cannot guess what it is - I opened it. About what time are you coming to Bangor Anna? I see by this paper that Avon and Martha Hill have lost their only child. How many have they buried besides the twins? I contemplate attending church again tomorrow if well. Shall have a washerwoman next week I think as Eliab brought home a number of dirty shirts, and I want to have some bed quilts etc. washed before we move. I am getting things arranged you see preparatory to moving. The Misses Beacroft called on me a few days since, with an invitation - to attend a sabbath school picnic in their neighborhood. Eliab went. I like them very much indeed. Mrs. Chase spent an afternoon here recently. I have quite a cunning book from the Library entitled "Bubbles from the Brunnen, by an old man," Lou would like to read it, Ann. Is is possible I have
Completed

Bangor Aug. 14 1852

                                                                                                                     Bangor Aug. 14. 1852

Dear Mother

                      We rec'd a very short, and apparently hurried letter, from Anne a few days since, and yesterday a similar one from Isaac & Antoinette. Very much obliged - and suppose I should address my letter to come one or more of the writers of those, but you know "dear Mother" generally comprehends the family. It is almost noon and I am writing in haste so as to send this to the Office by Eliab when he goes from dinner. Samuel has a box in the P.O. now, so we can get letters at all times. He has not been at all well for several days, but is much better now - did not go to the mill but two or three times for a week. Yesterday P.M. we called on Mrs. Thaxter, then to Mrs. Crosby's, took Margaret with us and called at Mr. Mason's, which we have so long intended to do, then back to Mr. Crosby's to tea. They

[left-hand side] I have made six pounds of flour into cake & got it all baked this forenoon. I am some tired.
Completed

had five other company's to tea. Margaret intends to return to Ipswich, though I do not believe she is well enough. We did expect Isaac & Nettie this week. Perhaps the letters forwarded with this will send him next week. I am afraid you keep Nettie dressmaking too much. I went to get buff cambric which Anne sent for and found her trunk locked. It was not in band basket.

               I have teased Eliab to write to you. he says he does not have time. So you ought some of you to write to him. He looked very indeed sad and fairly sick when he came home from Hampton but said nothing only "Maria is sick." After a few days he rec'd a letter, which he showed me,. The writer seemed to be in a very excited state of mind. The he told me that he considered her slightly deranged when he was there - she got very much fatigued & excited examination day, - seemed very much dejected & melancholy - thought she had done wrong to engage herself to him, as she had devoted
Completed

herself to the missionary work, and was very decided that it was her duty to break off the engagement. Eliab wished her to consider the matter while he staid - she did, & decided, the last thing before he came away, that it was best to give it all up, but promised to write to him once more. Well, in a few days come her letter, wherein she had entirely changed her mind. It commenced, "O that I could give wings to the message which Jesus permits me to send you etc." She said her friends had thought her rash & wrong in her decision, & she now felt that it would be right for her to accept him. Eliab hardly knew what to do. I did feel for him very much. I am afraid he runs a fearful risk if he marries her, in regard to her health, and if he should not, I think they would both be very unhappy. At first he did not wish me to write to you anything about it, but when I wanted him to write & get you to advise him, he said he couldn't, that I might write what I pleased. I think he will write you soon, & perhaps you
Completed

had better not say anything about it till he does. He wrote a most excellent letter to Miss Eby after recieving hers. I thought it was worded just right - he read it to me to see what I thought f it - you must be aware, that it was rather a difficult letter to write under the circumstances.

                The Aug. Messengers, Almeda's patch & dress are ready to go up. I am waiting till Nettie comes before I get the other articles. I have been to meeting two hay? days and expect to go again tomorrow.
                      Mrs. Charles Wiggin came home yesterday - has been at Boston three weeks under the care of Dr. Girardin - where she went away, was given up by Dr. Paine - could not walk a step - not expected to live but a few days - before she left Boston, walked 1 1/2 miles, took care of her sister, who was sea sick, on the way home, and this morning is perambulating the streets with the step of a well person! It seems really wonderful. We shall probably move the last of next month. In excessive haste - and much love.
                                                                                                                                                                       Lucy
Completed

Bangor Aug. 28 1852

                                                                                                                                Bangor Aug. 28 - 1852

Dear ones all

                          It is twenty minutes past five P.M. We had dinner at 1/2 past twelve, since which time besides making my toilet etc. I have worked a lace cap entire for Almeda.  Lucy was about sick yesterday - laid on the soda about all day. I feared would have a fever, but is much better today. been sewing most of the afternoon. Jane is getting tea. Isaac and Nettie gone shopping and to ride. Poor Nettie has been hurrying almost every moment since she came here - so wearisome & wearing too, attending meetings, am at the dentist's - A wearisome week the next will be for her, and then the packing, parting with friends and the long journey. I fear she will be sick.
             About Almeda's shawl, Nettie understood it very decidedly to get a black silk shawl at any rate - we
Completed

both thought a poor one would be worse than none. So got that. Isaac fretted wonderfully about it. It has been returned today, and Nettie is going to get a plain piece of black silk for a mantle with fringe for the ends. 

 Our house comes on finely. Mr. Tebbets will be out in a very few days - the painters are at work up stairs now. The store room and all about the kitchen is so convenient. We expect to move sometime in Sept. 
   Mr. T. considers himself discharged from here as soon as he can find another boarding place. Issac had had 12 or 15 dollars worth of daguerreotypes taken - some grand good ones - no poor ones. We are expecting you next Thursday without fail. Anna - when will Mother come? We were all invited to tea at Mr. Romulus Haskin's last evening (Mr. Tebbets and all) but at noon Mr. H. sent counter orders, as the children were sick, so we escaped that time. I hurried and got my new gown done to wear
Completed

too. It fits very prettily. I must not stop longer now - you can hardly imagine what a continuous whirling hurry we have all been in since they came. It seems as if we have no good visit at all, though we all try to enjoy it as we go along.

           Sabbath noon. Have been to church the forenoon - heard Mr. Caldwell have been for five or six sabbaths & not heard Mr. Shepard yet. Mother it is decided among your children here that you are to come down when Anna comes without fail to have your portrait painted - there is an itinerant artist in town of acknowledged talent who paints for a comparatively low price - you can never get a good daguerreotype, try as much as you will - so please do not say one word against it, but come - you ought to for our sakes. Eliab will write you about it. He will come to the house - so you need be at no
Completed

trouble about it. The whole matter is decided - there is no alternative but for you to come as quick as possible, as he does not remain here long. It is a rare opportunity. His portraits are said to be more perfect than Mr. Hardy's. Isaac and Eliab have examined them. Sam'l and all say come. Don't let Almeda's work hinder - that can be put off--this cannot. Bring it with you and I will do it. We have not touched the dress for Lucy - there has not been a half hour to spare.

              Eliab has finished his letter. I really thought he was going to write a good long one - you can see what he says - he seems to expect me to perform his duty for him. You must talk to him. In haste
                                           Lucy.
Completed

Bangor
Sept. 25. 1852

                                                                                                                               Bangor Sept. 25 - 1852

Dear Mother

                                              Your good letter was rec'd yesterday noon --greatly obliged - we really intended to write by yesterday's mail, but the same old story - we were so busy. The musical Convention, which Anne has attended but little, for lack of time, then she has been having a bonnet made, which she had to go down street to see about some - and we both went shopping one day - then yesterday Mrs. Shepherd and Lizzie Doe came to tea etc. etc. etc. We have scalded the plum preserve & dded sugar thereto, made tomato pickles & catsup, besides fixing over the bedroom, & front chamber carpets, and making a new woolen carpet for the entry - we found a remnant - very good and cheap. Anne and I have both got our new dresses made - we could not match the front chamber carpet - shall cover with bocking. Anne slept considerable the forenoon you went away, and
Completed

felt quite nicely in the afternoon. We are making a Bagatelle. Anne is just going down street, so I am writing a little just as fast as I can to send to the Office, that you need not be disappointed again Monday.

       Am sorry you had so unpleasant a time going home - glad Almeda is so "blooming and happy. I want to see her in her new abode dreffully - hope you will find your way up there soon. I hope Charles will bring us some butter - we can have no more from Mrs. Crosby's, and if she can spare it, shall depend on Albina's butter henceforth. We shall probably begin moving Tuesday. We had a letter from Nettie, dated Cleaveland, Ohio, last night - no news - pleasant journey - both well - presume you will hear from them as often as we shall. Lizzie is coming to spend the night & go to church from here tomorrow morning. She will probably be here considerable. We would with all our hearts, write advice and everything about Charlie's selling
Completed

the farm if we knew what to say. Of course we shall all talk according to the best of our ability when he comes down. I don't think of anything more to write and I must finish my carpet as Samuel want to put it down - good bye
do write often                            Lucy.
How did Albina like her things?
Completed

Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf,
                                                                     Milo
                                                                             Maine
Completed

Shepherd's being obliged to leave town next Friday. We felt it necessary to invited her with Mrs. Webster & Miss Doe here to tea Thursday - (tomorrow) - and it will make us somewhat hurried to get "ferry cake" made in season! I don't think of anything special to write, as Charles will tell you all. only that Sarah Harlow popped in to see the house before we had been here half an hour! Samuel got an Irishman and two wheelbarrows, and moved without a team. How soon are you coming to see us? I hope you will go to Brownsville soon. I think
[left-hand side] some section for her nice

                                                                                                                                       Bangor Sept. 29 - 1852

Dear Mother

                                We are moved, and, as you may imagine, in some confusion and disorder at present. Charles found us just thrown in, in heaps. not spread out at all. Anne is about tired out I imagine. I stand it admirably - my tough pot has not given out yet, though I confess I was a little the worse for the wear last night. My woman is here washing windows etc. This forenoon ...then
Completed

going to finish cleaning the other house, She washed Monday & ironed yesterday. Mr. Stevens is here finishing up things, varnishing a little etc. We shall get nicely settled in a few days. I hope ready to welcome our friends, who may be pleased to pay us a visit. We have really a good house - good enough for us - all we need to make us comfortable. I hope we shall be both thankful and happy. The only draw back to our present felicity is that owing to Mrs.
Completed

Shepherd's being obliged to leave town next Friday. We felt it necessary to invited her with Mrs. Webster & Miss Doe here to tea Thursday - (tomorrow) - and it will make us somewhat hurried to get "ferry cake" made in season! I don't think of anything special to write, as Charles will tell you all. only that Sarah Harlow popped in to see the house before we had been here half an hour! Samuel got an Irishman and two wheelbarrows, and moved without a team. How soon are you coming to see us? I hope you will go to Brownsville soon. I think a little, a very little of going to Milo when Samuel goes. I think I shall keep both cheeses, though I fear they may mould and spoil and dry up - the little one, which we have cut is very nice. The cream is a real treat -  what a splendid toast we had last night., and coffee this morning - it will be so nice for company tomorrow. Charles thinks you won't want the bottles, so I'll borrow them a while, except one, in which I'll send a little ketchup. Mr. Harlow is going to move down into his new house very soon - do write often good bye

              Lucy

[left-hand side] Tell Albina I'll try and make some section for her nice cream sometime.
Completed

When C. comes again send such picture-frames as you think we could use but I think the mourning poece better be left - the frame would not be suitable for other pictures.

 We have been in haste as usual are in confusion now looking forward still to time to read etc. E. had a letter from E. Hampton last week : would not show it. he did the last: about the school she said that if her sister did not conclude to take it she would write should like of all things to have but sister there and such nothing! in this last she said one of the trustees had had one in view all the time, that she was very much afraid her plans would not succeed but what her plans were she did not inform us.   
  I have not expected to go there. Think to go to Foxcroft next spring would be both more pleasant and better for me.
  E. I think feels anxious about various matters said last eve that he thought it doubtful whether he should stay all winter in Bangor: asked me if he had better be married this fall ---we have been in such a hurly burly lately that had been no time to talk. Lucy's dress left here & a cape that I send her.

[upside down] Bangor Sept. 29 '52
Completed

Bangor Oct. 26 1852

                                                                                                                                  Bangot Oct. 26. 1852

Dear Mother 

                     We have purchased Almeda's shawl. and as no other opportunity presents itself, we think of sending it by stage tomorrow. It is not so thick and warm as mine - such are hardly to be obtained now - hope she will like the colors. She sent no directions whatever in regard to color or price. With the shawl we send cotton damask for two table cloths, - one from Anne to you, one from me to Albina. I do not know whether they will retain their beauty! after washing or not, but will look nice a long time nicely for table covers.
                    Anne has been down street this morning. saw Eliza Ann Dow in Lavinia Kittredge's new shop at work. Eliab has had an offer - or perhaps not really an offer yet though - of a situation away up Fish river, in or near queen Vic's dominions, to superintend extensive lumbering operations, at $1000, or thereabouts per year. He talks as if he  means to go if he can get the chance. I believe he thinks it will undoubtedly pave the way for good and lucrative situations hereafter
Completed

Miss Ely will think it "going on a mission" in good earnest, I fancy.

                 What does Charles decide and do about selling his farm? We got a letter from you a day or two since, but you did not say a word about that. I have got pretty well over my ill turn. - quite about house again. Mr. Tebbets and two of his mean are building the fence. I had not idea it would be so much work.
                  We had a letter from Almeda a short time since. The children really seem to be entering society, in the way of paving bees etc. I think I shall not have Jane go to school next term, and so, if I am tolerably well do without a girl a while longer. I can't bear to have one so long as I can help it. How soon are you coming down Mother. We have been expecting Charles every day, almost, since Samuel was at Milo. Will he come before sleighing?
                  Is not Almeda coming down this fall before it comes bad travelling? I should think she would. We should like the butter when it is convenient to send it  but no hurry about it - also if you or any of the neighbors have eggs to spare, we should like a bucket or firkin of them, if they can be sent soon before danger of their freezing. If you kill biddies
Completed

so that there are from two to half a dozen wings to spare, tell Albina I should be very glad of them. We intend soon to invite a little company to tea. Prof. Shepard etc. that we talked of before you went away. don't you wish you was invited too? Samuel and I rode down to Hampden last Saturday. The first time I have been out for a long time. Abby Thaxter spent an afternoon and night here last week. We are going there soon. Jane has been quite unwell for a few days. I gave her a rochelle powder yesterday. She grits her teeth at a great rate nights - disturbs Anne ad Eliab in their chambers. Well what a parcel of nonsense I have written. It is 12 o'clock - I must see about dinner - good bye.

                                                                                                                      Daughter Lucy.

I should think C. might do well to get a steady Irish girl, if the right sort could be found it would be good help: or perhaps a man and his wife to work on farm year after year and have a little shanty to live in near by Eliab or Sam'l might perhaps find a chance after a time. I think it quite probable am Irish girl could be got, by trying & you surely must have? some one.
Completed

Dear Mrs. Ansthiss

       I remembered that Mrs. Kicher had engag'd to have her Daughter Maria board with you and work for her board which the school keeps.

Maria has been helping me save at week what she could for I have not been able to any other girl and I don't know now where I could get any one. You know how I am consumptive and I am not able to get along alone and I write this in confidence to ascertain whether you have any objection to her staying here 2 or 3 weeks before she goes to board with you.
Please let me know soon
& very much oblige your
friend ADK
[other side] Drawess?  School
Completed

Bangor Oct. 31, 1852

                                                                                                                                 Bangor Oct. 31- 1852

Dear Mother

                        It is sabbath day - all are at meeting except myself and Jane. I kept her at home for the purpose of doctoring her head with grease! Among other evils, she has got shockingly lousy by going to school. Yesterday I cut her hair all off close, & had her scruff thoroughly in hot soap suds - and today have combed and completely saturated her hair with grease. The term is but three weeks longer. I hardly know whether to have her finish or not. She has not learned near so much as she would have done at home. Yesterday Anne did a lot of baking and I made quince preserves and some apple jelly for our company, which we contemplate inviting this week intend to ask Elizabeth Jenks with them - she is spending some weeks in Bangor- called here last week. Samuel bought a dear little stove for the chamber yesterday -can be open or an air tight at pleasure - only $7.50 small. What do you do for a stove? I am afraid your room is not comfortably fixed. Guess I shall come up and see by and by, and make you
Completed

a Bagatelle. Anne and I made a nice one the other day - it is so convenient. We had letters from Isaac & Nettie a few days since. They probably have written to you again by this time. How are your eyes this winter? mine are not very strong - fear I shall not be able to see much evenings, which I ought to do. 
Elbridge & Mills Rider spent a night here last week. I want to go to Brownsville very much. Samuel bought a barrel of loaf sugar for only 8 1/2 cents a pound - much cheaper than brown at that price - it weighed 208 lbs- just as he had got it to the top of the back stairs alone, it slipped, and in spite of him got by him, and tumbled end over end clear down stairs and into the bedroom! He thought one time it would go over him, but it did not hurt him a bit; only bruised the stairs pretty badly. Our garden fence is in process of building. I want you should come down here and see how we look & should think you would want to see how yourself looks too. We keep you shut up om a dark room most of the time. I wish I could send Albina a tumbler of my apple jelly, but she can make some very easily, and it is so nice - just take a few apples, cut them in thin slices, cores, parings and all, stew them
Completed

till soft, then strain through a coarse cloth or sieve, taking care not to get too much of the apple itself through, - not much beside the juice, then add a pint of sugar to a pint of juice and boil half an hour or so, till, on cooling, it thickens - the apples want to be just covered with water - loaf sugar makes nicer than brown. It is nice. I would make a little, A tumbler of some such thing is great comfort in sickness. Isaac's letters are in future to be directed to Du Quoin, Perry Co. as that is to be his location for the present. I hope you will write to him often - we have all written, but in his last he said he had recieved no letter yet. How soon is Charles coming? It seems to me if Anne stays here this winter, you ought to be here too, as she may go away in the spring, and you not have so good a time to be with her again very soon. Samuel is going to have a horse and ? this winter, so I guess Anne and I will occasionally take passage with him as far as Milo and Brownsville when he goes into the woods. We can go one at a time you know.
Mond. P.M. Made some cranberry jelly this forenoon, that we may have the wherewithal to make "jerry cake." The vestry of the third church is plastered
Completed

We are in daily expectation of having news, from Milo. Please write it as soon as convenient. Anne and I went up to Glenburn to see Lizzie Doe one afternoon last week - we talked of keeping right on up to Milo. I have decided that I shall have no time to work on rug carpets this winter, so I am going to send what rags I have already served by the first opportunity, and I wish you would engage Mrs. Sargent to weave them. They will make two or three "strips," which will be convenient for various purposes, - so the store of rags you sent me, you had better take back again & make into a "hit or miss" rug, I guess. Samuel bought a dozen real pretty tea knives at auction for $2.00, almost as good as new, such as they ask $5.00 for. Please inform me if you can how much and what kind of stuff I had better get for warp. I have 10 lbs of rags. Samuel & Eliab have each taken a pair of your gloves. The rest Samuel thinks he can dispose of. I took one pr of stockings for Jane. Anne took the other. Such will not sell here. Please do write often. We are worried because you have no good stove in your room. Afraid you are not comfortable. If any of you have any more biddies' wings than you want to use, please save me a few.  In haste. good bye
Lucy.
